title-group.article-title: An iterative numerical scheme for the calculation of the effective moduli of heterogeneous materials with finite element method

article-meta.aff: 1School of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798
2Department of Hydraulic Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China 100084

author-notes.corresp: Q Yang, Department of Hydraulic Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China 100084 Email: yangq@tsinghua.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: An iterative numerical scheme to calculate the effective moduli of a heterogeneous material is presented based on the finite element method. The effect of the inclusions on the effective moduli of the heterogeneous material is embodied in a virtual local body force caused by eigenstrain within the equivalent homogeneous material in the scheme. The effective moduli of the original material are achieved by iteratively calculating the virtual local body force with the adoption of two systems of mesh in the scheme. The meshes in the first system discretize the whole domain and serve as the finite element meshes to obtain the solution, and the meshes in the second system discretize the inclusions. The difficulty of mesh generation due to inclusions is overcome by the complete independence between the two systems of mesh. Examples are presented to verify the validity of the scheme, and its convergence rate is also discussed. Application of the scheme is conducted to study the effect of inclusion shapes on the anisotropy of composite.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The determination of effective moduli of a heterogeneous material is a classical problem and has many engineering applications. The effective moduli of a heterogeneous material depend on many factors, such as the properties of the inclusions and matrix, the inclusion volume fraction, inclusion shapes, and inclusion distributions. Great attention has been paid in the research community to predicting the effective moduli of heterogeneous materials analytically and numerically, with many achievements being made till now.

The well-known analytical methods for the estimation of the effective moduli of a heterogeneous materialare the dilute method,1 the self-consistent method (SC),2,3 the generalized self-consistent method (GSC),4 the differential method (DM),5 the Mori-Tanaka method (M-T),6,7 and the interaction direct derivative estimate (IDD).8 All these methods are based on Eshelby’s9 fundamental work on the stress field of an isolated ellipsoidal inclusion in an elastic infinite matrix and on mean-field approximations over the representative volume element (RVE). The difference between these methods is on how they consider the interaction between the inclusions. It is required in these methods that there exists an analytical solution of eigenstrain induced by the inclusion. Although great progress has been made to obtain the analytical solutions for eigenstrains, they are only achieved in special cases where the inclusion shapes are regular. For the case of irregular inclusions, these methods are not reliable, as can be seen in Ref [10].

Alternatively, numerical methods have been proposed to predict the effective moduli of a heterogeneous material with the consideration of inclusions with arbitrary shapes, such as the asymptotic method,11 the multipole expansion method,12 the boundary element method,13 and the finite element method (FEM).10,14–16 Among these numerical methods, the FEM is the most dominant and popular. The main difficulty for FEM is mesh generation when the inclusions are irregular and multishaped. Various measures have focused on how to reduce the difficulty. These measures include the application of digital image technique, where each pixel and voxel represents a two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) finite element, respectively,17–19 the unified application of state-of-art software packages,10,16 and the combination of extended finite element techniques combined with level set method.20,21 However, mesh generation for heterogeneous materials with arbitrary inclusion shapes is still not an easy task, especially when the domain is 3D and the inclusions are numerous, and their shapes are irregular.

In this paper, an iterative numerical scheme based on FEM is proposed to calculate the effective moduli of a heterogeneous material. In this scheme, the effect of inclusions on the effective moduli is embodied in virtual local body forces, which is caused by eigenstrains in a homogeneous media. The effective moduli are achieved by iteratively calculating the virtual local body force, with the adoption of two systems of mesh in the scheme. The meshes in the first system are used to discretize the whole media and serve as the finite elements to obtain the solution, and the meshes in the second system are used to discretize the inclusions. The difficulty of mesh generation is circumvented due to the complete independence between the two systems. After a thorough literature search, we did not find any previous approach like ours. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In the section Theoretical basis, the concepts of eigenstrains and the virtual local body force, which serve as the theoretical foundation of the new scheme, are introduced. In the section Numerical scheme, a scheme to calculate the effective moduli of a heterogeneous material within the framework of the FEM is presented. Verification, applicability and convergence analysis, and some application of the scheme along with some discussions are supplied in the section Results and discussion. Some conclusions are made in the section Conclusions.

sec.title: Theoretical basis
sec.p:
The constituents of a heterogeneous material are divided into matrix and inclusions, which are denoted by ΩM and ΩI in Figure 1(a), respectively. The elastic mechanical behavior of the media is governed by the constitutive law and the condition of equivalence, of which the equations are: (1) and (2) Figure 1.
Heterogeneous media and its equivalent homogeneous media.

In Equations (1) and (2), σ is the stress tensor, f is the global body force, ε is the strain tensor, which is equal to the symmetric part of the gradient of displacement u, CM is the stiffness tensor of the matrix part ΩM, CI is the stiffness tensor of the inclusion part ΩI, (∇·) is the divergence operator, and (:) is the double dot product operator of two tensors.

With the introduction of eigenstrain ε*,9 a heterogeneous material with an inclusion is set equivalent to a homogeneous one with eigenstrain produced where the original inclusion was located as shown in Figure 1(b). As eigenstrain is stress-free, Equation (1) is rewritten as (3)
According to the second term in Equations (1) and (3), we have (4)
Here, we consider the instance of a homogeneous media composed of the matrix Ω, with extra force (5)
The extra force is exerted on ΩI as shown in Figure 1(c). The ε*(x) in Equation (5) is the same as that in Equation (3). The governing equations of the instance are: (6)
And (7) where, (8)

It is easy to see that Equations (6) and (7) have the same solution for ε(x) as Equations (1) and (2), if they have the same specified displacement boundary condition Su and stress boundary Sσ as shown in Figure 1(a). So once ε(x) is found by solving Equations (6) and (7) with the specified boundary conditions, the effective moduli of the original heterogeneous can be calculated easily with the known ε(x) and Equation (1). Therefore, the original heterogeneous media is treated as a homogeneous one, with extra local force f*(x) exerted on the initial inclusion part. Here, f*(x) is defined as a virtual local body force. The effect of the inclusion on the effective moduli is embodied by the virtual local body force.

sec.title: Numerical scheme
sec.p: The weak form of Equation (6) combined with Equation (7) expressed in displacement formulation is (9) where the δu is the variants of the displacements and should satisfy the confinement imposed by Su. According to Equations (7)–(9), we have: (10)

So, the FEM equations for Equation (10) can be written in the form as (11) where K is the stiffness matrix formulated according to the elastic properties of the matrix, U is the global displacements at the finite nodes, F is the discretized form of ∫SσTdS+∫ΩfdΩ, and F* is the discretized form of ∫ΩIf*(x)dΩ.

In this numerical scheme, the key point is how to calculate F*(Uk) in the case where the inclusions are irregular and numerous, and ideal mesh generation is difficult to accomplish. Two systems of elements are introduced to tackle this problem. The elements in the first system, as shown in Figure 2(a) with dashed lines, are actually the traditional finite elements used to discretize the whole domain Ω without consideration of the inclusion, and elements in the second one, as shown in Figure 2(a) with solid lines, serve to discretize the original inclusion ΩI and are referred to as subelements. The two systems of elements are completely independent of each other, so the difficulty of mesh generation which arises from various irregular inclusions is completely avoided. Figure 2.
Finite elements and subelement (a) and nodes and subnodes (b) in the numerical scheme.
With the introduction of the two independent element systems, F*(Uk) is calculated asymptotically using the following procedures, with the 2D case (plane stress or plane strain) taken as the example.

First, it is easy to see that for any ue',j',k, the j′-th subnode displacements of the subelement e′ at the k-th iterative step as shown in Figure 2(b), it is calculated by interpolation with: (12) where (ξj ' e,ηj ' e) are the local coordinates of the subnode j′ located in the finite element e as shown in Figure 2(b), Ns(ξ,η) (s = 1, 2, …, m) are the shape functions of the element e, ue ,s, k are the s-th node displacements of the element e at the k-th iterative step, and m is the number of shape functions of element e.

Second, according to Equations (4) and (5), Fe ',i ',k, the equivalent concentrated force acting on the i′-th subnode of the subelement e′ at the k-th iterative step, which results from thedicretization of F*(uk) in the subelement, is calculated by (13) where n′ is the number of subnodes of the subelement e′, kI,e ', and kM,e ' are the stiffnesses of the subelement e′ derived based on the properties of the inclusion and matrix, respectively, and ue ',j ',k are the j′-th subnode displacements of the subelement e′ at the k iterative step.

Finally, the calculation of F*(uk) can be achieved by transferring the concentrated forces Fe ',i ',k acting on all the subnodes of all subelements to the finite element nodes using the following formula, which is based on the principle of virtual work (14)

In Equation (14), Ns(ξ,η) (s = 1, 2, …, m) are the shape functions of the element e, where the subnodes i′ are located as shown in Figure 2(b), (ξj ' e,ηj ' e) are the local coordinates of subnodes i′ in the finite element e, m is the number of shape functions of element e, n′ is the number of the subnodes in subelement e′, and l′ is the number of subelements.

sec.title: Verification
sec.p:
A two-phase composite model similar to that in Ref [22] is taken as an example to verify the validity of the numerical scheme. The cubic composite with isotropic matrix and inclusions has eight identical inclusion spheres. The x–y (z = a/4 or 3a/4) and x–z (y = a/4 or 3a/4) cross sections are shown in Figure 3, of which a is the edge length (characteristics size) of the RVE of the composite. The inclusion volume fraction c, ranging from 0 to 0.5, is altered by changing the radius of the nonoverlapping eight spheres simultaneously. The matrix and inclusions have the same Poisson’s ratio, equal to 0.25. The ratio of EI to EM is 10–5, of which is EI and EM are the elastic moduli of the inclusion and matrix, respectively. Figure 3.
x–y (z = a/4 or 3a/4) and x–z (y = a/4 or 3a/4) cross section of the representative volume element (RVE).

The results from the numerical scheme are compared with those from some classical analytical solutions, as well as with the results from finite element analysis conducted here. The finite elements in the numerical schemes, as shown in Figure 4(a), consisted of 40 × 40 × 40 linear hexahedral elements. The characteristic size of the subelements used to discretize the eight spheres was half of the characteristic size of the finite elements in the numerical scheme. The subelements were mainly linear hexahedral elements but also included some linear wedge elements. The subelements of a single sphere with radius equal to 0.244a (c = 0.50) are shown in Figure 4(b). The finite elements in FEM were linear tetrahedral elements, and for the case with c equal to 0.5, the elements are shown in Figure 4(c). Figure 4.
The finite elements (a) and subelements (b) in the numerical scheme, and the finite elements in finite element method (FEM) (c; not scaled).

The normalized effective bulk moduli and shear moduli of the composite, as calculated by different numerical and analytical methods, respectively, are shown in Figure 5. It is seen from Figure 5 that when the inclusion volume fraction is very low (c ≤ 0.05), the existing well-known analytical methods predict the bulk moduli and shear moduli of the composite very well. The reason is that when c is low, the interaction between the inclusions is not very strong and no large errors occur if the two-phase media is treated as the case of a dilute suspension.22 With the exception of the M-T, IDD, and GSC methods, the effective bulk moduli calculated by the analytical methods, increasingly differ from that obtained from the FEM with increasing amounts of c, while the results in this paper are very close to that of the FEM over the full range of c (0 ≤ c ≤ 0.5). Figure 5.
Effective bulk moduli (a) and shear moduli (b) by analytical and numerical methods.

It is shown in Figure 5(b) that none of the shear moduli, predicted by the analytical methods, agrees well with that obtained from the FEM when c is larger than 0.2, while the shear moduli predicted by the numerical scheme match well with the results obtained from the FEM over the full range of c. Two important conclusions are drawn from this example. The first one is that none of the existing analytical methods can predict well both the bulk moduli and shear moduli of the composite, when c is larger than 0.05. The second one is that the results from the numerical scheme have excellent agreement with those from the FEM for any c (0 ≤ c ≤ 0.5).

sec.title: Convergence and applicability analysis
sec.p: A special case, where c is equal to 1.0, and the matrix and inclusions are isotropic and have the same Poisson’s ratio, are taken to analyze the convergence and applicability of the numerical scheme. According to Equations (3)∼(5), Uk and Uk + 1 have the following relationship: (15)

It is seen from Equation (15) that the absolute t should be less than 1.0 to ensure the convergence of the numerical scheme. Therefore, the numerical scheme is applicable to the cases where the inclusions are softer than the matrix for any c. However, numerous tests showed that for the cases where EI is equal to or more than two times EM, the convergence never occurs for any c. The reason is that the local t at the inclusion part is equal to or less than –1.0, and the local nonconvergence at the inclusion part leads to the global nonconvergence. In summary, the numerical scheme is confined to the cases where the inclusions are softer or not much harder than the matrix.

It is also seen from Equation (15) that the convergence rate of the numerical scheme is related to the stiffness ratio of the inclusion to the matrix. Two limit cases with the same model, similar to that in Figure 3, were conducted to show the convergence of the numerical scheme. In the first case, EI/EM is equal to 10–5, and in the second case EI/EM is equal to 1.99999. The volume fraction c in the two cases is equal to 0.5, and the matrix and inclusion have the same Poisson’s ratio equal to 0.25. In each case, a numerical hydrostatic loading and a numerical shear loading were applied separately.

In Figure 6, K¯f and G¯f are the normalized effective bulk moduli and shear moduli of the composite calculated by FEM. It is seen from Figure 6 that even with c up to 0.5 and with EI/EM up to its limit ability, thenumerical scheme converges very quickly. The effective bulk moduli and shear moduli calculated by the scheme become stable within 120 iterative steps. This means that the computational cost incurred by thescheme is acceptable even with c up to 0.5. Figure 6.
Convergence trend of the numerical scheme for numerical hydrostatic pressure test (a) and shear test (b).

sec.title: Application
sec.p: In this section, the numerical scheme is applied to calculate the effective moduli of the composites in two examples. There are two emphases in Example 1. The first one is to study the effect of inclusion shapes on the effective moduli of composite, and the second one is to recheck the accuracy of the scheme with different inclusion shapes. Example 2 is applied to show the applicability of the numerical scheme to composites with numerous irregular inclusions.

Example 1. Four cases of composite were considered in this example. There were eight identical inclusions in each case. The inclusions in case 1 are circular cylinders, the inclusions in case 2 are cubes, the inclusions in case 3 and case 4 are triangular prisms. The x–y cross section of the RVE in each case is shown in Figure 7, where the profiles of the inclusions are depicted by dashed curves. The heights of the inclusions are equal to their own characteristic sizes b, which are shown in Figure 7. The cylinders, cubes, and prisms are arrayed with their longitudinal axis parallel to z-axis. The z coordinates of the centers of the inclusions are either a/4 or 3a/4, and a is the edge length of the RVEs. In each case, the inclusions and matrix are isotropic with EI/EM equal to 0.1, and they have the same Poisson’s ratio of 0.2. The inclusion volume fractions in the four cases are 0.3. Figure 7.
x–y (z = a/2) cross sections of the representative volume elements (RVEs).

The finite elements in the numerical scheme in the four cases were identical, which were 40 × 40 × 40 linear hexagon elements as shown in Figure 4(a). The characteristic sizes of the hexagonal subelements in thefour cases were half of that of the finite elements. The subelements of a single inclusion in each case are shown in Figure 8(a)–(d), respectively. To recheck the accuracy of the scheme with different inclusion shapes, FEM was applied here to calculate the effective moduli of the composite in each case. The characteristic size of the linear tetrahedral elements in FEM is the same as that of the tetrahedral elements in Figure 4(c). Figure 8.
Subelements of a single inclusion in each case.

The normalized diagonal components of the effective compliance matrix Sii (i = 1 ∼ 6), calculated by the numerical scheme, and their relative errors eii (i = 1∼6) in the four cases, are listed in Figure 7.The relative error was defined as below (16)
In Equation (16), Sii f(i = 1 ~ 6) are the diagonal components of the effective compliance matrix calculated by FEM.

It is seen from Table 1 that except in case (b), where the composite has cubic geometric symmetry,23 the composites exhibit noticeable anisotropy in the other three cases. For case (a), the composite is more compliant in the z direction than in the x and y directions, while for cases (c) and (d), the reverse is true. This means that the anisotropies of the composites are significantly affected by the inclusion shape. The maximum e in Table 1 is 2.97%, the minimum e is 0.01%, and the average e is 1.55%. This means that the diagonal components of the compliance matrix obtained from the numerical scheme have good agreement with those obtained from FEM. Table 1.
Normalized diagonal components of the compliance matrices and their relative errors (%)
Case S11 e11 S22 e22 S33 e33 S44 e44 S55 e55 S66 e66
(a) 1.578 1.11 1.578 1.11 1.994 1.88 1.551 1.21 2.082 1.12 2.082 1.12
(b) 1.633 0.01 1.633 0.01 1.633 0.01 1.744 1.69 1.744 1.69 1.744 1.69
(c) 1.802 2.40 1.802 2.40 1.562 0.27 1.972 2.38 1.833 2.97 1.833 2.97
(d) 1.846 2.25 1.782 2.21 1.545 0.79 2.024 2.11 1.796 2.31 1.792 1.56

The 21 components of the effective compliance matrix Sij(1 ≤ i, j ≤ 6) in case (d) are listed in Equation (17), and the corresponding 21 components of Sij f (i, j = 1 ∼ 6) are listed in Equation (18). It is assumed that Sij (Sij f) is assumed to be zero if the ratio of its absolute value to S11 f is lower than 10–4. (17) (18)

It is seen from Equation (17) that the nondiagonal components of S in case (d) can be divided into two groups. The first part consists of the upper left nondiagonal components Sij (1 ≤ i, j ≤ 3, i ≠ j). The components in the first group have good agreement with their corresponding Sij f. Although the other nondiagonal components of S which are classified into in the second group have large relative errors, they have a minute even negligible effect on the constitutive behavior of the composite. Similar situations occurred in the other three cases. In summary, the numerical scheme is reliable within its capability.

It must be pointed out that although the inclusion shapes are different from each other in the four cases, the finite elements are identical for the four cases when applying the numerical scheme. In the four cases, the RVEs and the inclusions in them were discretized separately and independently when applying the numerical scheme. Therefore, there does not exist any difficulty in mesh generation for this numerical scheme.

Example 2. There are nine inclusions in this example, which are shown in Figure (9). The sphere inclusion, of which the radius is 0.155 times of the edge length of the cubic composite, is located at the center of the composite. The inclusions and matrix were isotropic with EI/EM equal to 0.3, and they have the same Poisson’s ratio of 0.3. The inclusion volume ratio is 0.265. The finite elements in the numerical scheme are shown in Figure 4(a). The subelements of the inclusions are shown in Figure 9. Figure 9.
The inclusions and their subelements.
The 21 components of the compliance moduli calculated by the numerical scheme are shown in Equation (19). (19)

It is seen from Equation (19) that normal deformation has little contribution on generating shear stress, and shear deformation has little contribution on generating normal stress in this example. This phenomenon is also observed in Ref [20]. The overall behavior of the composite is slightly anisotropic.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, a new numerical scheme based on the FEM is proposed to calculate the effective moduli of a heterogeneous material. The effect of an inclusion on the effective moduli of a heterogeneous material is embodied in the virtual body force caused by eigenstrain. The difficulty of mesh generation is completely overcome by this scheme as two independent systems of elements are adopted. The convergence rate of the scheme is satisfactory and the computational cost induced by the numerical scheme is acceptable. The results by the numerical scheme have been shown to be reliable in comparison with those obtained from a standard FEM. Application of the scheme shows that inclusion shape has a significant effect on the anisotropy of composite. The limitation of the numerical scheme is that it is not applicable to the case where the inclusion is much harder than the matrix.

ack.p: The first author gratefully appreciates the advice and comment from Dr S.S. Chen, as well as from the anonymous reviewers.
